In December 2004, the Council adopted a regulation establishing standards for security features and biometric data in passports and travel documents issued by member states.
Now, we have needed to create new spaces in order to combat the rapid and trafficking of children.
The authorization of passports for children, in accordance with the principle of one person one passport, may be a fundamental means of winning this difficult and important battle.

In my country, Portugal, the collection of fingerprints from children as young as six years old is already a practice with a long tradition, which, perhaps for that reason, does not cause me any objection.
As a defender of the European cause, I believe that in this matter it is important to have harmonization.
It is reassuring to know that member states, such as Portugal, which have long set a minimum age of six years for collecting fingerprints, will not have to amend their national legislation.
I must emphasize that the security of the passports that it reinforces is not exhausted in the existence of a passport.

The passport, by itself, corresponds to an increase in the level of security, which ranges from the presentation of the necessary documents for the issuance of passports, followed by the collection of biometric data, up to the verification and matching at border control posts.

Nothing has gone well there; it has had a coup d'état, a civil war, and lives in great political instability, military tensions, deep rivalries, and recently also a very worrying and increasingly evident presence for all observers interested in drug trafficking.
We strongly condemn these bomb attacks that killed the chief of staff Taggumen in the EU and also the particularly barbaric, not to say savage, murder of President Ni Vieira.
Regardless of their past, we express our solidarity to their families, to the people of Guinea-Bissau, and we deeply regret and condemn these attacks.
We have left the path towards normality and the lesson I have learned, which I would like to emphasize in the resolution, is that impunity is not a remedy.
In the past, regarding the murder of Suman de Mané and the journalist Veríssimo Ceabra, how is it that a blind eye was turned so that the guilty parties were not found and brought to justice?
It is evident that this is not a surprise.
Moreover, we must make it clear to the State of Guinea Bissau that those responsible must be found, the guilty must be brought to justice, and we must provide all the necessary help.

I also want to draw attention to the concern about the presence of drug trafficking throughout the region, the risk it represents for the European Union, and the shocking presence of it in Guinea Vial.

Mr President, in the face of the urgency, what we witnessed in Copenhagen was several steps backwards.

It is true that Copenhagen mobilized more heads of state than others, but they also wanted more divisions. As a result, what happened was that we ended up with a situation of every man for himself, where each state can defer what its goals are and, on top of that, a voluntary regime.
It is of no consolation to us that we have a two-degree Celsius target or targets for funding, without any clarification.
And so, what I think is that we have to act in terms of the future, and acting in terms of the future is about moving from rhetoric to action.
The European Union has always wanted to be a leader, it has always stated so.
But when we got to Copenhagen, it turned out that he would not define or defend the goals that he had stated here as his own goals and which he would not write down.

And so, what I ask is whether, in the future, we will not be more just if we continue to allow, at the expense of this failure and the decisions of some over others, the poorest to continue paying the highest bill.

The President's Green Paper on the reform of the common fisheries policy, for which my colleague from the Azores, Maria do Céu Patrão Neves, is the rapporteur, is a unique opportunity for a debate on a sector that is of great importance for the balanced local development of the outermost regions.

Madeira is following the ongoing discussion with particular interest and believes that it is imperative to propose a differentiation between artisanal and industrial fleets, which should be subject to different fishing regimes.

In forestry, priority is given to supporting the modernization of vessels, as well as measures that ensure the conservation of a comprehensive group of species in the long term.

President, the European Union recently celebrated an agreement with Latin American countries within the framework of the World Trade Organization, in which it committed to substantially and progressively reduce tariffs on banana and tuna imports.

I would like to remind you that the situation of producers in these regions is already seriously hampered by the physical and orographic characteristics of the islands and the size of their farms, which lead them to face permanent difficulties that penalize their development.

It is therefore urgent to take measures in defense of the producers of Madeira and Canary Islands bananas, taking into account the serious and immediate impact that the new Geneva agreement has on the European import market and, consequently, on the production and marketing of bananas from these outermost regions.

Thank you, Mr. President, President, your commissioners, colleagues, we are facing an acceleration of a global change that has devastating consequences for our economic, political and social systems and, consequently, for all our citizens.
We have witnessed today an unprecedented weakening of the capacity of states to respond.
The European Union must therefore identify common causes and allies and act clearly and united on the world stage.
Extraordinary situations require clarity in joint action.

If we do not take the necessary measures of rigor and collective accountability, Europe will be doomed to marginalization and impoverishment, and only a strong Europe, respectful of its common rules, will be able to respond adequately to the new times.
Weak and divided states are not capable of protecting their citizens.

Therefore, we need to be able to regain the confidence of citizens, win the battles of stability, budgetary discipline, job creation, stability of the monetary union, globalization, and strategic choices.
This felt like a penalty for having our future compromised.
And it wins the future by betting on social cohesion, ensuring peace, building a new model based on values of freedom, social justice, and responsibility.
Thus, the Europe 2020 strategy and the Europe 2020 integrated guidelines are essential tools for a new cycle of growth and employment in Europe.
For proper implementation and achievement, it is necessary to define quantifiable and clear objectives in employment, education, and poverty reduction.

It is also crucial for the success of the strategy that everything is done to facilitate the transposition by the Member States of their national objectives and to ensure the correct implementation of this strategy. Thank you.
When the Economic and Monetary Union turned ten, the commission considered it the Union's most successful project.
Today we would have difficulty affirming it without limitations, because the crisis showed the evidence that the Economic and Monetary Union is an unfinished project.
Minimal rescue measures were taken in an emergency climate, but let us not be mistaken: the conditions of pressure, the direct interests of the main players
Member countries, the painful nature of the decisions, and their slowness have weakened the image of the euro and the European Union in the eyes of citizens and the world.
Facts must be faced.
The European Union and Europe are a process of integration; they are not merely inter-country cooperation.
The unfinished work that is currently being reinforced runs the serious risk of disappearing.
There are three issues that need to be addressed. First, it is important to consolidate the instruments that were launched in this climate of emergency. A monetary fund must be created.

In Europe, we need to move forward with Eurobonds, we need to move forward with the European supervisory and regulatory architecture, and we need to move forward with a European dimension in the management of banking crises.

In this regard, it is important to understand that there is no such thing as a strong currency if the economy is weak. The one percent growth forecast for the European Union is unsustainable in terms of
Whether in terms of its demographic composition or in terms of combating unemployment, the 2020 Strategy is nothing more than a collection of good ideas if it lacks the means to implement them.

Third dimension, Commissioner Ol Re, fiscal consolidation is important, but it cannot coexist with growing divergences among the member states that make up the Union. The convergence policy must be urgently revised. Thank you for being President.
thank you, Mr President. Several colleagues here from the EPP have already provided a very comprehensive overview of the situation.

And the conditions for the single currency to be strengthened and for this project of monetary and economic integration to move forward.

That the mistakes that the socialist government has made in Portugal over these 15 years, and which today, unfortunately, are visible to all, need to be corrected and will have the support of the PSD to be corrected.

But if we are supporting austerity measures, we also criticize the Portuguese government and it is a good example for other analogous cases, because it is not reducing spending. And what is crucial is not just

It is not enough to increase taxes to reduce the deficit, but to reduce spending, to demand that the government has the courage to take measures that reduce spending, that reduce the deficit, that alleviate the public debt.
This applies to Portugal and to other States that are today in a difficult situation. And we, as parliamentarians and Europeans, have the responsibility to do the same in our countries.
An apology for the measures necessary for the euro to emerge stronger and for this space of integration and this dream, which is a dream of the EPP and a dream of all of us, to become a reality.

Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by saying that the report on the evaluation of the results of the 2006-2010 roadmap for equality between men and women and aimed at influencing strategies on this matter for the future could, in our opinion, have been more assertive and less controversial.

In fact, the way to approach several highly sensitive issues, particularly the issue of women's sexual and reproductive health, should have been different if the goal was really to achieve the greatest possible consensus.

That being said, I would like to emphasize that during times of normal economic growth, concern for women's rights, particularly the disparity between the situation of men and women in the workplace, in society, and in the family, is significant. However, these problems are significantly exacerbated by economic and social crises, such as the one we are currently experiencing.
Hence, there is a need for a reinforced strategic commitment from the member states at the level of local and regional entities and of the community institutions with regard to protection.

This means that, in line with what President Dou said and what colleague Werner Langen said, it is essential that there is an economic government of the Union, but that this economic government is centered in the commission.
This is the first point I wanted to emphasize. I mean that we should not only, as we do today, every morning, have our debate focused on immediate issues, but also...
Also in those that are part of Strategy 2020, and I emphasize, in particular the issue of education and training of the young, the issue of innovation, research and development.

Because these are the niches that will allow Europe to be competitive in the global space. And today I must say that, unfortunately, the European educational model has failed, and failed, when compared to the model of emerging countries.

Like India, like China, like Brazil, it is now a less demanding and less rigorous model, and therefore, I also ask that, in the boldness of this idea of innovation, development, research and education, there be rigor and demand within the context of European educational systems.
Only with this rigorous standard of excellence can we prepare our young people to compete in the global market.

We cannot just think about the crisis of this year or the next two or three years, we have to think about the strategy for Europe in the next ten to twenty years and it depends on an educational system of rigor and diligence.
Commissioner, never before has the European project, built with so much effort over the past 50 years, been so threatened.

The frustration of European citizens is enormous. The financial system that was supposed to serve them has destroyed their savings, their pensions, their investment projects, their jobs, in short, their future.
As for the necessary strengthening of the entire financial services market, banking, insurance, securities, the way forward is clear and lies in the architecture we are discussing here today.
We are, in fact, in need of a strong European supervisory architecture that covers all products of actors, which is equipped with methodologies and instruments of
effective intervention that is capable of responding to the reality of the market, which, especially in the European context, does not recognize national borders.

Risk cannot and should not be eliminated from the financial market, but we need regulation that makes this risk more transparent and prevents the accumulation of bubbles whose explosion affects the entire system and spreads to the real economy.

But if, despite these defenses, new crises occur in the future, it is crucial to have mechanisms in place to limit contagion, especially with regard to the banking system, because it is vital for the functioning of the economy and the custodian of citizens' savings.

Here, precisely in the powers and competences of the banking authority, lies the capacity to implement a new strategy on the management of cross-border crises in the banking sector, a topic addressed in my report.
It is not in our hands to prevent the bankruptcy of banks, but rather to ensure that their reorganization or eventual liquidation is carried out in a
In an orderly manner, limiting the side effects on the rest of the system and, above all, preventing the taxpayer from having to pay for the costs of the crises they generate.

A set of new devices is needed for this. It is necessary to adopt rules, definitions, methodologies, instruments and terminology common to all parties involved in restructuring, reorganization or liquidation operations.
It is necessary to harmonize the relevant national legal frameworks for crisis management, particularly bankruptcy and liquidation laws.
It is necessary to assign supervisors with extended powers of intervention.
It is necessary to establish clear criteria, not only quantitative but also qualitative, that allow for the initiation of interventions in an institution experiencing difficulties.
Contingency plans need to be prepared.
This entire process for twenty-seven member states takes time.
However, about 50 banks out of the 12,000 operating in Europe account for 70% of the assets.
Now, this means a huge concentration of risk, but also an opportunity to intervene on them as a priority.

There are conditions for proposing a special and urgent process for the consolidation of banks that, due to their cross-border nature, size, and relationships with other banks, have a possible systemic impact on the financial system.
Or, for these banks, it is possible to anticipate special supervision by the new European banking authority, although operating within the College of national supervisors.
It is possible and urgent that they, due to the risk they generate, start making contributions to a fund that finances potential interventions.
if necessary, it is important that the banking authority creates a specialized unit to intervene in case of difficulties in these banks.
Overall, the proposed elements ensure that interventions in transnational banks of a systemic nature are consistent and coherent across the
different countries and, above all, that a principle so dear to Europe is upheld: that the costs of pollution caused by these banks should be borne by the polluter themselves.
This proposal fits perfectly with what we are discussing, especially regarding the powers of the banking authority. I would even say that it is the most evident test of its effectiveness.
In the case of the vote in the economic and monetary committee, there was an overwhelming majority in support of this proposal, with 87 votes.
We also have here in the plenary the massive vote of this institution, in the sense that by massively supporting this proposal that is visionary, that is realistic, but that is pragmatic, we
Let us take action that is urgent and necessary to rekindle the hope of Europeans in Europe, in its financial system and, in particular, in the banking system.

Deforestation, as we know, is one of the main environmental and social problems on the planet and every year we lose 13 million hectares of forest, contributing to 20% of the globe's carbon emissions and posing a huge threat to biodiversity.

The contribution of deforestation to climate change is undeniable and, as such, it is largely responsible for the occurrence of extreme weather events and floods, or even for the desertification of vast areas of the planet.
Floral loss puts all of humanity at risk, but this risk and impact is not shared equally among us.
Communities with fewer resources and those that depend most on the forest and nature to survive are the most affected.
Deforestation concerns our collective existence, the scarcity of natural resources, their distribution, the rights of local and indigenous communities, and social justice.
The main cause of deforestation is illegal logging, which accounts for 20 to 40 percent of global industrial wood production.
Therefore, we are also talking about the transfer of wealth from the producing countries to the consuming countries of that same wood.
This illegal practice jeopardizes the sustainable exploitation of timber and the companies that do so.
Pretty words are not enough.
This Parliament must adopt strong measures in this fight.
This report takes a very significant step in that direction by defining the prohibition of timber trade.
Good intentions are not enough either.
Means and measures are necessary, particularly sanctions, which in this case can be of three types.

Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner. My first words are to praise the work done by the rapporteur. My colleague from Jogiovacaquis has done an extraordinary job in identifying the text structures of energies for enhanced effectiveness among the various structural funds.

Your report also features in this joint debate on cohesion policy, a debate that assumes greater importance not only because of the substance of the topic, but also, above all, because of the timing of its discussion.
In fact, we are currently in a position to know the commission's proposal, not only regarding the new financial perspectives, but also regarding the future cohesion policy post-2013.
The common policy is a fundamental policy for the European Union.

It is a horizontal policy that, through its primary instruments and structural funds, finances projects and programs in the member states, seeking to reduce the disparity between the development levels of the various regions.
Experience, however, has shown us difficulties in terms of disability and results that stem from the fragmentation and complexity of this policy.

A single strategic framework for the various funds, as an integrated and results-oriented approach, is the starting point for more and better synergies between the various instruments and for enhancing their effectiveness.
It is also essential for better coordination between the various sectoral policies and for greater efficiency in the application of resources.
We must take advantage of the period of crisis to seek new alternatives.

And it is certain that all these reports that are being discussed here today will pose enormous challenges, and we know that to respond to these challenges, we also need a good budget, but we must make a clear distinction between the budgetary aspects and the political objectives.
The political objectives are well known and, in fact, only by affirming these political objectives can we offer a future to the regions.
And if that is the case, we must then put the budget at the service of the future of the regions and the citizens, and not the citizens and the regions at the service of the budget. Thank you.
Mr President, cohesion policy is a key policy for the future of the European project.
The construction of a common space with an internal market and a common currency requires a certain level of convergence among its member states and regions in order to function.
The current divergences in competitiveness and development asymmetries have inevitably led to the weakening of the European area and the crisis affecting the eurozone.
This is why this vital need for convergence absolutely requires a powerful cohesion budget that cannot be weakened to finance other policies.
The European Union, in order to do more, must have more, and this is achieved by increasing its budget and not by reducing, even if cleverly, the cohesion budget.

I ask the Commissioner, therefore, whether the creation of the fund for infrastructure and the new innovation policies that will be linked to cohesion and regional development, which I support, without an increase in the Community budget, could not turn into the Trojan horse that is introduced into the cohesion budget.
The modernization and renewal of the energy infrastructure are essential factors for the sustainable and smart growth objectives we seek with the 2020 Strategy and for the energy security we need.
Previously, they thought about involving all regions in this challenge.

To this end, the incentives provided for in the regulatory systems must be improved, especially those that apply to higher-risk projects and more innovative projects, such as those being developed in the Azores in the field of renewable energy.

The regions must be involved in the project grant and implementation phases, in setting priorities, in their development and execution, because this ensures better results and, therefore, better defence of European interests.
The current economic moment further accentuates the need to adopt an innovative and integrated approach to energy issues, taking into account all economic, environmental, and social aspects.
It is imperative not to lose sight of its medium and long-term effects, seeking to ensure that all European citizens have access to secure, sustainable, and affordable energy.

Mr President, the number of homeless people as well as people living below the poverty line has been increasing in recent years in several member states
The economic, financial and social crisis and the increase in unemployment have exacerbated this problem, as everyone has already diagnosed.
We also all agree that this phenomenon is the negation of important values of the European Union, respect for human dignity and respect for fundamental rights.
In my country, for example, which is subject to a strong austerity measure, the homeless concept, according to the national plan, encompasses people who go to ask for help to have a meal.
And the number of people seeking help to eat has increased by more than 20% since 2008.
Note the greater increase in families and impoverished people who have seen their living situation altered by unemployment and also include bank debt.
This is just one example that demonstrates the seriousness of this situation.
Last year, the European Parliament adopted a written declaration on a European Union strategy for the homeless.

With this statement, this Parliament has highlighted the need for the European Union to develop a strategy supported by national and regional strategies, with the long-term goal of ending situations of people sleeping on the streets and long-term homelessness.
National strategies should focus on preventive measures, but there are also concrete actions to improve the quality of services provided to the homeless and the availability of affordable housing.
It is also evident that this European strategy must be compatible with the social housing policy of the member states.

First and foremost, one must ask why revise VAT in the European Union?
First and foremost, there is the need to be compatible with the single market.
The more regimes and VAT varieties, the less fluid the market will be.
A VAT reform favors e-commerce, centers competition on the value of goods and the base price of goods and services, rather than on tax differences.
Combats fraud and ensures much-needed trust, especially in cross-border transactions. Improves the economy of the PMS and reduces administrative burdens.
other measures when givens are already in place in the single market that may relate to this
First and foremost, a simple, clear, and transparent digital support mechanism tailored to the 7th single market.
Measure five, on services, the need to review legislation on standardization and the implementation of the directive
The new measure is intended to remove tax obstacles and explicitly review the VAT system and VAT equalization in online and face-to-face commerce, which we all feel when we order books.
The pressures for VAT reform have two main reasons.
First of all, the economic crisis.
More revenue is needed, including, probably in some countries, reducing contributions on labor to promote economic development, shifting this burden to VAT.

In second place, the second major source of pressure is population aging, demographic aging, and the trend of shifting from indirect to direct taxes, which, due to the reduction in the population base, has an impact.
It is necessary to rethink the balance between this direct and indirect taxation.
Finally, we must, in these reforms, reconcile subsidiarity with harmonization.
It is necessary to narrow down the range of variation in the standard VAT rate so that we can all understand it better.
Greater transparency is needed in defining the reduced VAT rate and its scope, a clear and widely publicized list of reduced rates.
It is necessary to study the exemption limits for PMS, knowing well that each exemption entails a risk of small or large-scale fraud.
Finally, welcome the commission's recent proposal to create a European VAT.

to the shadow rapporteurs, with whom I have had a fruitful collaboration, and I also thank the rapporteurs of the partners from the four committees involved. These partners are a valuable contribution to this report.
We received 400 amendments and drafted 4 or 7 commitments that were all approved.
This demonstrates the importance and interest generated by this topic of new skills and jobs.
It is ultimately about preparing Europe's human resources, anticipating the needs of the labor market in the next decade.
The key strategy for drafting the report was to reformulate common ideas to avoid repetition and ensure the report's coherence.
I think that this objective has been achieved
We all know that the crisis currently affecting us has highlighted the weaknesses of the European economic and social model, and has also negated many of the progress made in the past.
Since the first effects of the crisis began to be felt in the labor markets in 2008, Europe has already lost more than five million jobs.
Today, nearly twenty-three million people have jobs.
Youth unemployment is even more frightening. The youth unemployment rate is close to 21% and represents more than double the general unemployment rate.
On the other hand, in all member states, unemployment rates vary with qualification levels.
This means that people with higher qualifications find jobs more easily.
We also know that, in the near future, the need for skills, competences and qualifications will increase in all types and levels of profession.
In this context, Europe faces four challenges: first, job creation; second, the need to develop and remain competitive.
Then there is the sustainability of social security systems and finally the difficulty in finding people with the right skills to fill job vacancies.
This report thus has a dual objective: first, to underline the need to act quickly to address skills gaps in Europe; second, to better anticipate the needs of the labor market in terms of skills.

To achieve this, several measures stand out. First, to ensure the availability of skilled labor, it is necessary to improve basic skills, as well as skills in science and innovation, information and communication technologies, and foreign languages.
As I mentioned earlier, skill needs must be identified early on, with a time horizon of at least ten years.
We are now aware of the potential of a new sustainable economy, the green economy, and the need for investment in ecological qualifications.
Then, participation in lifelong learning, professional requalification, and reducing school dropout rates must be increased.
Another important issue is the mutual recognition of diplomas and professional qualifications and the urgency of moving forward with this recognition.
Fourthly, we draw attention to the link that must exist between educational establishments and the needs of the labour market.
Internships must be of high quality and supervised by tutors so that they can lead to employment and put an end to any abuses of the situation of interns.
Particular emphasis is also placed on the role of social partners and social dialogue.
The report also proposes measures to promote job demand and creation.
We have the future ahead of us and we have to create jobs.
Small and medium-sized enterprises play a decisive role in achieving this goal.

It is also necessary to strengthen the single market to facilitate the free movement of workers and, consequently, the need for the coordination of social security systems so that workers can have their acquired rights guaranteed, especially the portability of pensions.

Finally, the issue of labour market flexibility. To improve the functioning of the labour market, the rules of flexibility and security must be adapted to the socio-economic contexts of each Member State. Thank you.

Poverty is indeed a very serious problem that requires effective and rapid action to stem the rise of the phenomenon that typically affects more than 80 million Europeans.

President, access to the internet should today be considered as a new fundamental right of citizens and not just as a mere object of commerce, because of this right
It includes essential things like freedom of expression, access to and sharing of information, access to sharing of culture and knowledge, as well as democratic and media pluralism.

And that is why this access cannot be subject to speculative tariffs or contracts that restrict free choice and the possibility of easily changing providers, particularly in the mobile telecommunications world, as we also know.

Internet shutdowns are not only exclusive to political regimes that are afraid of their people.

That is why Parliament is committed to clearly upholding net neutrality and defending its open nature.

We have been taking medication for three years to get out of the crisis and the situation is getting worse day by day.
Instead of healing, we have created two fatal vicious circles.
The first one between banks and the state.
In Europe, it is now easier to discuss the bankruptcy of a state than that of a large bank, but it is still widely believed that banks finance states and that states save their banks.
This spiral has to be broken.
The mission must move forward with European legislation that protects taxpayers from bank crises.
But it is also vital to protect the debt of states and individuals from speculators' attacks.

To this end, it is urgent and overdue to prepare the coordinated emissions of sovereign bonds, whether called Good Bonds or Stability Bonds, and guarantee them through robust instruments of a community nature, not an intergovernmental one.
In short, we also need to review the involvement of the European Central Bank.
But the second vicious circle results from the argument that some states are rich because they are virtuous, while others are poor because they have sinned.
This narrative is politically explosive and technically wrong.

It ignores the essential fact that a single market and a single currency built by political choice among unequals necessarily exacerbate competitiveness imbalances between the center and the periphery.
And this is what needs to be addressed in economic governance.
It is not resolved through sanctions and promoting the crushing of wages and incomes through one country's control over another.

Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, the maritime policy advocates a coordinated approach to the management and governance of oceans, seas and coasts, from a global and coherent perspective of all European policies related to the sea.

A global perspective and an integrated approach imply the interaction of European policies related to the sea and require better governance through greater involvement in the European decision-making process.
The success and relevance of this policy have been demonstrated over the past few years through various funded initiatives in the form of preparatory actions and pilot projects.
Integrated maritime policy must therefore continue to benefit from adequate funding during the next few years of the current financial programming period.
In this sense, I advocate for adequate funding until 2013, not only to consolidate previous projects and support financed by a stable framework regarding the objectives of this program.
Issues of policy, governance, sustainability, and maritime surveillance are, for obvious reasons, topics of particular interest to some regions of the European Union, such as the outermost regions.

The eruption regions, with the exception of the French war, being small and irascible, depend on a reduced number of economic activities, and in which activities related to the sea and fishing assume special importance.
Furthermore, the outermost regions contribute to the European Union having the most extensive exclusive economic zone in the world.

As groups P represent more than half of the European Union's exclusive economic zone, about 15 out of 25 million square kilometers, and are, together with coastal regions, fundamental to the economic growth of the European Union and its Member States.
A programme such as an integrated maritime policy should benefit these regions by giving priority to transnational coordination of maritime policies and relevant international cooperation.
It is therefore necessary to ensure continuous and sufficient funding, not only for the next two years, but also and above all for the next financial framework starting in 2014.
It would be a missed opportunity to fail to harness the enormous potential that the Atlantic and Mediterranean dimensions hold for the European Union when discussing integrated maritime policy.

The Atlantic, being the western maritime border of Europe, also establishes its connection to North and South America and Africa, conferring a strategic dimension to Europe that is indispensable in the architecture of a maritime policy designed with an eye to the future.

And it is with the future in mind that the integrated maritime policy, in addition to promoting the coordination of maritime activities, should place the potential of the Atlantic in its three-dimensional dimension based on science and technology at the forefront of its priorities.

The investigation of the deep sea and the seabeds of the Central Atlantic is a new frontier whose potential exists in biotechnology and mineral resources and is of inestimable value for the knowledge economy.
The Union should therefore take advantage of the privileged position of the telescopes and the expertise of its department to be installed at the Marco de Profundo observatory. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President, I think we are at a time of assessment regarding these crisis policies and austerity measures that have affected so many countries, as well as the so-called structural reforms.
And it is in this context that I think we cannot help but see how they have generated so much social commission.

And it has generated social commission not only in the most difficult countries, in the poor countries, not only in the so-called PIGS (Portugal, Italy, Greece, and Spain), but also in other contexts in Europe.
Last week, we had the largest strike in Portugal's history, involving both the public and private sectors, a strike that took to the streets.
But if we look at people in the UK, we see that we have witnessed the largest strike ever, especially if we consider that people also took to the streets as they did in Portugal.
We expect a large demonstration in Brussels on Friday.

What this proves, Mr. President, and what the strikes prove and the people's taking to the streets proves is that the causes and problems we have been facing are common, and that is why the reaction is also common.
The crisis of the European Union is infecting all member states, reaching unbelievable proportions.

We are witnessing chaos in the financial markets and a growing inability to secure essential financing for the operations of our small and medium-sized enterprises, even those that are healthy, leading others to bankruptcy and unemployment.
It is a spiral that fuels the recession and is destroying the economy and society.

No one denies the strict need for budgetary discipline, deep restructuring, and more economic governance, but these are necessary conditions that, in the short term, are no longer sufficient to counteract the ongoing degradation in the Union.

And if it is true that policies are needed to discourage employment and growth, without which we will never be able to control the surplus debts, the central issue today is to ensure the financing of our companies and our economies, without which the Union will collapse.
That is why, more than ever, more than a revision of the treaties, we need today a strong and secure intervention by the European Central Bank.

Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating my colleague Íbur on her excellent work and pointing out the coincidence that, on the day of Europe that we celebrate today, we are debating and will adopt measures that meet the legitimate aspirations of our citizens tomorrow.
What is at stake in this regulation is to impose limits on mobile phone tariffs charged to European consumers when roaming, with the ultimate goal of ending roaming within the European space by 2016.
Our citizens will now benefit from a sharp drop in prices for GSMMS calls and data.
If nowadays there are operators that charge three euros per mega, from July, the maximum price they will be able to charge is 70 cents per mega, with this value increasing to 20.25 cents in 2014.
As for incoming calls, the maximum price that can be charged will be eight cents this year and five cents in 2014.
In July 2012, a family with two mobile phone users will, as the Commissioner said, save 200 euros on their bill.
Second benefit: higher quality of information for consumers.
Starting in the summer, operators will be required to inform consumers of the prices charged when they travel outside the European Union.
until now the obligation was only within the European space.
Third advantage: the possibility of more operators entering the market, which means increased competition that will stimulate better services and better prices.

Finally, in the near future, the consumer will be able, if they so choose, to have two contracts - one for service in the national territory and another for service abroad - while keeping the same mobile phone number and receiving only one bill.
Consumers, our citizens, will also be given the option to contract with any European operator that offers the best price.
This report is the perfect example of the Europe of citizens, the Europe of freedom of movement and freedom of establishment. Thank you very much.
In February 2009, this Parliament approved a report supporting the European Commission's proposal to relaunch the European economy
There were projects on clean energy, transport, new technologies and innovation, and the role of the European Investment Bank and the Structural Funds was already being considered at that time.
More than three years later, we were able to produce the Six Pack, the Two Pack, the Fiscal Compact, the Two PECs, all of them full of reinforced discipline in sanctions.

But meanwhile, as unemployment, especially among the young, reaches frightening levels, the European economy is entering a recession, and more than seven of its member countries are experiencing negative growth.
However, and while Greece is no more than a first stone threatening to bring down the castle, the relaunch agenda seems to have been forgotten.
At the moment, this agenda is clear.
What matters at this point is no longer to attribute a sense of urgency, but a sense of emergency, in a situation that threatens to explode.
A set of pillars urgently needs intervention.
First and foremost, the European Marshall Plan must be made up of investments that promote growth, employment, and convergence.
Project Bons are one of the possible sources.
Secondly, it is necessary to stabilize the interest rates at which countries finance themselves.
Let us at least prepare to coordinate the issuance of surplus debt and jointly manage the accumulated debt.
Thirdly, the European Stability Mechanism and the European Central Bank must prepare to actually function as real firewalls in defense of European sovereign debt.
Fourthly, the credit that was massively transferred by the European Central Bank to commercial banks must reach companies.
A billion euros is held back in the banking system, while thousands of viable companies die every day due to lack of financing.
Point five: investment makes no sense without demand.
The most fragile economies are crushed by austerity plans.
It is the strongest economies that need to stimulate internal demand.

That's because nearly all of the exchanges do their business within Europe, and it's up to the commission, Mr. Commissioner Ol Rene, to make recommendations directed not only at the most fragile economies, but also at the most dynamic ones.
And finally, I conclude, Mr. President, that we must set a limit on the revenues and taxes imposed by the troikas.

We must put an end to the punitive style, without dialogue and without accountability, with which high-ranking officials determine the fate of millions of European citizens and the democratic institutions of member countries. Thank you, President.

Thank you very much, Mr President, European leaders keep insisting on budgetary discipline, and I ask myself, budgetary discipline, so let's get to it, because what exactly are we talking about when we talk about budgetary discipline?

In my view, budgetary discipline means respecting contracts with pensioners and not abandoning state commitments halfway through. In my view, budgetary discipline means respecting the contracts of those who work and not inventing extraordinary taxes or cuts in subsidies.

The fundamental thing is to respect commitments in health, education, and culture, and not to close services or cancel projects halfway through. The discipline is to put the banks in order and not to take money from taxpayers to put it in the hands of speculators to save their banks.
This is the fiscal discipline I would like to see implemented in the European Union, rather than continuing with this market party.
